txt.en: Instance: Nár's Tale
'And so, Nár toiled to set a small encampment at Azanulbizar.'
'As another day of waiting drew to its end, Nár slipped into dreams.'
'Well? Come on, then.'
'In his mind, Nár beheld Thrór standing triumphantly before the East-gate.'
'Behind him, a chorus of hammers and song echoed from the halls of Khazad-dûm.'
'Such a joyous end to the quest Nár could have hardly imagined.'
'But it would not be so.'
'In need of respite, Nár urged Thrór to take rest.'
'Although Thrór had set his mind on entering Khazad-dûm, he relented.'
'But Thrór cared not.'
'Axe in hand, he went in, as proud as any dwarf ever crossed the doorstep of Khazad-dûm.'
'No, no, none of that!'
'After all, this was not so long ago by the reckoning of Durin's folk!'
'And that is where our tale begins....'
'Together, Thrór and Nár went north.'
'All in Zudrugund bade farewell to Thrór, though they knew naught of his quest.'
'In old Eregion, Thrór insisted against the West-gate, and the two continued northward.'
'After a time, they crossed the Redhorn Pass and descended into Azanulbizar.'
A Mysterious Voice
'Yet, to the surprise of his kin, Thrór did not set off on his journey alone.'
'In the dwarves' absence, it had become an unfamiliar and unfriendly land.'
'With him, he took a single companion: Nár, his friend and esquire of old.'
'The dale had long fallen silent, and what remained of the Great-way was choked with undergrowth.'
'Yet there, beyond the brambles and brush, laid Thrór's prize: the lost kingdom of Khazad-dûm.'
'We know you're there, beardling.'
'We've been watching you.'
'But never fear... we won't take your head today.'
'And it'd be no fun puttin' your other eye out after what you've seen.'
'Nár stopped at once, frozen in horror.'
'No, you'll make a fine messenger yet.'
'Out of the darkness had flown a body, its limbs all a-tangle...'
'You see what we do to beggars and vagabonds who barge through these doors?'
'...and nearby a head lay before the gates of Khazad-dûm.'
'He got what he had coming, the old thief, trying to filch what’s ours.'
'You lot bring your reeking whiskers around these parts again, and this is what you'll get!'
'And so Nár waited.'
'You tell them that! Tell them all!'
'It's the least we can do, eh boys?'
'And waited... until he feared he could no longer bear it.'
'And when his family asks who killed him and who's king here... THAT will be your answer.'
'Now... off with you!'
'Garn, have a look! It’s right there on his face where I wrote it!'
'You can read, can't you?'
'That's right! I'm the master of this house!'
'Leave it be, beggar-beard! That's mine now!'
'Breaking the silence, a distant voice shouted in the Orkish tongue.'
'Here, some coin for your troubles!'
'A horn blared, harsh and ugly, out of Moria.'
'And from the East-gate came a sickening thud, echoing through Azanulbizar.'
'Fear for Thrór seized Nár's heart.'
'Yet loyal as ever and heedless of all peril, Nár drew his sword.'
'Abandoning his hiding spot, he rushed up the steps to the East-gate.'
'Take heed, my friend.'
'An ill wind blows in this vale.'
'It is time, Nár.'
'I have lived long enough in exile.'
'You have proven your loyalty, my friend, and I ask only that you await my return.'
'And then, out of the darkest shadows of Moria came a voice...'
'Do not fear, dear Nár. I go to honour our forefathers!'
'And so, Nár fled weeping from Khazad-dûm.'
'And waited.'
'Nár knelt to inspect Thrór's head, and upon it was carved the name: \qAZOG\q'
